worksheet.title: Discovery guide

introduction.p:
Consider the matrices
I \amp = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{bmatrix}, \amp E \amp = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 2 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \end{bmatrix}, \amp A \amp = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \\ 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 3 \end{array}\right].

task.p: Remind yourself using the row-times-column pattern of matrix multiplication why I A = A is true.

statement.p: Notice how E is only one entry different from I. How does this change the process of computing E A compared to computing I A?
Think of multiplication by E as transforming A into the result matrix E A. How could you describe the transformation in this particular example?

hint.p: In the transformation A \to E A, which rows of A stay the same, and which rows change? For the rows that change, how exactly do they change?

task.p: Do you think the same thing will happen when computing E times some other matrix?
We know that E I = E. But then consider E I in terms of the first two parts of this discovery activity. So in terms of row operations, what is the relationship between E and I?

statement.p: Create a 3 \times 3 matrix E' so that for every 3\times n matrix A, the result of E' A is the same as performing the row operation multiply row 3 by -4 on A.

hint.p: What was the pattern you identified in Discovery?

statement.p: Create a 3\times 3 matrix E'' so that for every 3 \times n matrix A, the result of E'' A is the same as performing the row operation swap rows 1 and 2 on A.

hint.p: What was the pattern you identified in Discovery?

worksheet.p: Matrices E,E',E'' from the discovery activities so far are called elementary matriceselementarymatrix. As the preceding activities demonstrate, every elementary row operation has a corresponding elementary matrix.
worksheet.activity: Suppose we were to take a 3 \times \ell matrix A and compute E'' E' E A = E'' \bbrac{ E' (E A) } , where E, E', E'' are as in Activities. How can we interpret this matrix multiplication result in terms of row operations? (Careful of the order of operations!)

statement.p: Determine elementary matrices E_1,E_2,E_3 so that E_3 E_2 E_1 B is the identity matrix.

task.p: The matrix B happens to be invertible. Manipulate the formula E_3 E_2 E_1 B = I algebraically to obtain a formula for \inv{B} involving your elementary matrices.

statement.p: Tack an identity matrix I onto the right end of your formula for \inv{B} from . (Recall that multiplying by I has no effect.)
Using this new, modified formula for \inv{B} as inspiration, come up with a procedure to use only row operations (and not elementary matrices) to compute the inverse of a square matrix.

hint.p: Where did your elementary matrices E_1,E_2,E_3 come from? And what are they now doing to the identity matrix, and in what order?

statement.p: Where there any other assumptions about the entries of A (besides a \neq 0) that you needed to make for this to work? Why?
